TF: EJS is a simple templating language that allows you to embed JavaScript code directly within HTML markup.
EJS can be customized to use any character for delimiters.
<% Outputs the value into the template (HTML escaped).
<%= Outputs the unescaped value into the template.
CommonJS Importing a module: import { function1, function2 } from './module.js';
CommonJS Exporting from a module: export { function1, function2 };
ES6 Importing a module: const module = require('./module');
ES6 Exporting from a module: module.exports = { function1, function2 };
This tag includes the template named: show from the folder <%- include('user/show'); %>
ES6 Importing a module: import { function1, function2 } from './module.js';
ES6 Exporting from a module: export { function1, function2 };
CommonJS Importing a module: const module = require('./module');
CommonJS Exporting from a module: module.exports = { function1, function2 };
CommonJS imports and exports are resolved at compile time.
ES6 Modules are loaded dynamically at runtime.
CommonJS Modules are natively supported in modern browsers using import and export syntax.
CommonJS modules are supported since version 12 but must be used with the .mjs file extension or by configuring package.json.
ES6 modules are the standard in Node.js.
ES6 modules, in browsers, require tools like Browserify or Webpack to bundle them for use.
type: 'module': This indicates that the package is an ECMAScript module (ES module).
type: 'commonjs': This indicates that the package is a CommonJS module.
Common.js-style modules can have a .js or .cjs extension.
ES6-style modules can have a .js or .mjs extension.
CommonJS is asynchronous, while ES6 is synchronous.
